questions.question_text_1: Read the following passage and answer the given subquestions:  Open AI Staff ‘Warned Board New System Threatened Humanity’  Open AI was reportedly working on an advanced system that was so powerful that it caused safety concerns among staff at the company before Sam Altman’s sacking. The artificial intelligence model triggered such alarm with some OpenAI researchers that they wrote to the board of directors before Altman’s dismissal warning that it could threaten humanity, Reuters reported.  The model, called Q* – and pronounced as “Q Star” – was able to solve basic maths problems it had not seen before, according to the tech news site The Information, which added that the pace of development behind the system had alarmed some safety researchers. The ability to solve maths problems would be viewed as a significant development in AI. The reports followed days of turmoil at San Francisco-based Open AI, whose board sacked Altman, but then reinstated him after nearly all of the company’s 750 staff threatened to resign if he were not brought back. Altman also had the support of OpenAI’s biggest investor, Microsoft.   Many experts are concerned that companies such as OpenAI are moving too fast towards developing artificial general intelligence (AGI), the term for a system that can perform tasks at human or above-human levels of intelligence – and which could, in theory, evade human control. Andrew Rogoyski, of the Institute for People-Centred AI at the University of Surrey, said the existence of a maths-solving large language model (LLM) would be a breakthrough. He said: “The intrinsic ability of LLMs to do maths is a major step forward, allowing AIs to offer a whole new swath of analytical capabilities. It’s a big step forward.”   In an appearance at the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation summit, Altman said: “Four times now in the history of OpenAI, the most recent time was just in the last couple weeks [sic], I’ve gotten to be in the room, when we sort of push the veil of ignorance back and the frontier of discovery forward, and getting to do that is the professional honour of a lifetime.” Open AI was founded as a nonprofit venture with a board that governs a commercial subsidiary, run by Altman. Open AI states that it was established with the goal of developing “safe and beneficial artificial general intelligence for the benefit of humanity” and that the for-profit company would be “legally bound to pursue the nonprofit’s mission.” The emphasis on safety led to the speculation that Altman had been sacked for endangering the company’s core mission.   Excerpted from:   Milmo, Dan. “Open AI Staff ‘Warned Board New System Threatened Humanity.’” The Guardian, 24 Nov 2023.

The model, called Q* – and pronounced as “Q Star” – was able to solve basic maths problems it had not seen before, according to the tech news site The Information, which added that the pace of development behind the system had alarmed some safety researchers. The ability to solve maths problems would be viewed as a significant development in AI. The reports followed days of turmoil at San Francisco-based Open AI, whose board sacked Altman, but then reinstated him after nearly all of the company’s 750 staff threatened to resign if he were not brought back. Altman also had the support of OpenAI’s biggest investor, Microsoft.   Many experts are concerned that companies such as OpenAI are moving too fast towards developing artificial general intelligence (AGI), the term for a system that can perform tasks at human or above-human levels of intelligence – and which could, in theory, evade human control. Andrew Rogoyski, of the Institute for People-Centred AI at the University of Surrey, said the existence of a maths-solving large language model (LLM) would be a breakthrough. He said: “The intrinsic ability of LLMs to do maths is a major step forward, allowing AIs to offer a whole new swath of analytical capabilities. It’s a big step forward.”   In an appearance at the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation summit, Altman said: “Four times now in the history of OpenAI, the most recent time was just in the last couple weeks [sic], I’ve gotten to be in the room, when we sort of push the veil of ignorance back and the frontier of discovery forward, and getting to do that is the professional honour of a lifetime.” Open AI was founded as a nonprofit venture with a board that governs a commercial subsidiary, run by Altman. Open AI states that it was established with the goal of developing “safe and beneficial artificial general intelligence for the benefit of humanity” and that the for-profit company would be “legally bound to pursue the nonprofit’s mission.” The emphasis on safety led to the speculation that Altman had been sacked for endangering the company’s core mission.   Excerpted from:   Milmo, Dan. “Open AI Staff ‘Warned Board New System Threatened Humanity.’” The Guardian, 24 Nov 2023.

questions.question_text_1: Read the following programme brochure and answer the given subquestions.  The Kala Ghoda Arts Festival 2020  The Kala Ghoda Art District is a crescent shaped precinct, with its concentration of museums, art galleries, educational institutions, boutiques and restaurants, has the finest array of heritage buildings in the city, and has emerged as an important art and cultural centre, thronged by visitors and tourists from across the globe. The Kala Ghoda Association was formed with the idea of giving back to the city it calls home by giving life to the biggest street art festival that India has seen- the Kala Ghoda Arts Festival. It is the country’s largest multicultural festival, and it takes place [Edit i] each year in February. The festival draws visitors in large numbers not only from the city but also from all over the country and the world. With the funds from The Kala Ghoda Arts Festival and the support from generous sponsors, the Kala Ghoda Association has helped to physically improve the area, restoring buildings and facades, installing people-friendly street furniture and improving the amenities available.  1st FEB SATURDAY   • What’s the Point? with Arzan Khambatta and Deepti Nair   CSMVS Lawns 11:00 a.m. - 12:30 p.m.   The start of every ingenious creation is a dot, and when that dot goes for a walk, it becomes a line. [Edit ii] Lets connect the dots in free space using beads and wires to create magic. (Age: 8 yrs +)   • Faber-Castell Artivity - Kandinsky’s Concentric Circles by Know Your Art   CSMVS Lawns 1:00 p.m. - 2:00 p.m.   Join us to create your interpretation of Kandinsky's iconic work The Square with Concentric Circles at the Know Your Art workshop. (Age: 6 to 12 yrs)   • Bored - a street play followed by The Story Room conducted by Tejaswini Patwardhan and her team of Open Minds Productions   CSMVS Lawns 2:00 p.m. - 3:30 p.m.   Bored encourages kids to have unstructured time to ponder over, get creative or simply interact [Edit iii] with each other, where as The Story Room is a fun and interactive session of lateral thinking and creative writing for the parent-child duo. (Age: 6 to 12 yrs)   • World of Coding with CodeW/Floppy  CSMVS Lawns 3:30 p.m. - 4:30 p.m.   Play a maze with algo or dance to the tune of loopy, in our fun & interactive world of programming, presented by CodeW/Floppy. [Edit iv] Stay SMART & remain SAFE online, learn about cybersecurity by cracking codes in this fun exercise presented by CodeW/Floppy. (Age: 5 to 12 yrs)   • Making the World with Laura Simms   CSMVS Lawns 5:00 p.m. - 6:30 p.m.   Laura tells a beautiful Seneca story called “The Woman Who Fell from the Sky,” a tale of good overcoming bad [Edit v] and a love for nature followed by children creating [Edit vi] a mural with dots of the images of the story from their imagination. (Age: 8 yrs +)   Adapted from: Kala Ghoda Arts Festival 2020. Kala Ghoda Association.

[Edit iv] Stay SMART & remain SAFE online, learn about cybersecurity by cracking codes in this fun exercise presented by CodeW/Floppy. (Age: 5 to 12 yrs)   • Making the World with Laura Simms   CSMVS Lawns 5:00 p.m. - 6:30 p.m.   Laura tells a beautiful Seneca story called “The Woman Who Fell from the Sky,” a tale of good overcoming bad [Edit v] and a love for nature followed by children creating [Edit vi] a mural with dots of the images of the story from their imagination. (Age: 8 yrs +)   Adapted from: Kala Ghoda Arts Festival 2020. Kala Ghoda Association.

props.summary:
Here’s a structured **summary of core topics, concepts, and principles** for the **"English I (Computer-Based Exam)"** paper, along with **Mermaid knowledge graphs** to visualize relationships between key themes.

---

### **Core Topics & Concepts**
The exam tests **4 broad areas**:
1. **Reading Comprehension** (Passage-based questions)
2. **Grammar & Syntax** (Punctuation, sentence structure, parts of speech)
3. **Vocabulary & Semantics** (Synonyms, antonyms, word replacement, idioms)
4. **Phonetics & Linguistics** (Syllables, stress, sounds, phonetic markers)

---

### **1. Reading Comprehension**
#### **Key Concepts**:
- **Main Idea & Supporting Details**: Identify the central theme (e.g., OpenAI’s Q* model threatening humanity) and supporting evidence (e.g., staff warnings, Altman’s reinstatement).
- **Inference**: Draw conclusions from implicit information (e.g., "Altman’s sacking may relate to safety concerns").
- **Fact vs. Opinion**: Distinguish between objective facts (e.g., "Q* solves math problems") and subjective opinions (e.g., "AGI could evade human control").
- **Author’s Purpose**: Determine why the author includes specific details (e.g., to highlight ethical concerns in AI development).
- **Context Clues**: Use surrounding text to define unfamiliar words (e.g., "turmoil" → "confusion").

#### **Passage-Specific Notes**:
- **OpenAI Passage**:
  - **Q*** (pronounced "Q Star"): An AI model capable of solving **unseen math problems**, raising **AGI (Artificial General Intelligence)** concerns.
  - **Key Events**:
    - Staff warned the board about Q*’s risks.
    - Altman was sacked but **reinstated** after staff threatened to resign.
    - Microsoft (OpenAI’s largest investor) supported Altman.
  - **Themes**: Ethical AI, corporate governance, technological breakthroughs.

---

### **2. Grammar & Syntax**
#### **Key Rules**:
- **Punctuation**:
  - Commas: Separate clauses (e.g., *"The Kala Ghoda Art District, thronged by tourists, has heritage buildings."*).
  - Hyphens: Compound adjectives (e.g., *"people-friendly street furniture"*).
  - Semicolons: Join independent clauses (e.g., *"Bored encourages creativity; The Story Room focuses on writing."*).
- **Sentence Structure**:
  - **Subject-Verb Agreement**:
    - Singular/plural nouns (e.g., *"Either Sana or Maitreyi **is** at the party."*).
    - Collective nouns (e.g., *"The board **regulates** standards."*).
  - **Tenses**:
    - Present simple (e.g., *"The school **hosts** a festival."*).
    - Past perfect (e.g., *"The xerox machine **had not been** working."*).
  - **Conjunctions**:
    - Coordinating (FANBOYS: *for, and, nor, but, or, yet, so*).
    - Subordinating (e.g., *"The baby is crying **because** it is hungry."*).
- **Articles**:
  - *"A"* before consonants (e.g., *"a long time"*).
  - *"An"* before vowels (e.g., *"an hour"*).
  - *"The"* for specific nouns (e.g., *"the Gateway of India"*).

#### **Common Errors**:
- **Misplaced Modifiers**: Ensure adjectives/adverbs modify the correct word (e.g., *"She almost drove her kids to school every day."* → Ambiguous).
- **Parallelism**: Maintain consistent structure (e.g., *"restoring buildings, **installing** furniture, and **improving** amenities."*).

---

### **3. Vocabulary & Semantics**
#### **Key Skills**:
- **Synonyms/Antonyms**:
  - *Trigger* → **Produce** (synonym); *Turmoil* → **Calm** (antonym).
  - *Alarmed* → **Frightened**; *Reinstate* → **Restore**.
- **Word Replacement**:
  - *"Swath"* → **"Area"**; *"Emphasis"* → **"Stress"**; *"Speculation"* → **"Supposition"**.
- **Idioms**:
  - *"Two peas in a pod"* → Very similar.
  - *"Sit on the fence"* → Avoid taking sides.
  - *"Turn a blind eye"* → Ignore intentionally.
- **Modal Verbs**:
  | Modal | Use Case                          | Example                                  |
  |-------|-----------------------------------|------------------------------------------|
  | Could | Past ability/probability          | *"She **could** solve the problem."*      |
  | Should| Suggestion                        | *"We **should** keep away."*             |
  | Shall | Offer/future intention            | *"**Shall** I watch the baby?"*         |
  | Must  | Logical conclusion/necessity     | *"It **must** be true."*                 |
  | May   | Possibility                      | *"She **may** not come."*                |

---

### **4. Phonetics & Linguistics**
#### **Key Concepts**:
- **Syllables**:
  - *Speculation* → **4 syllables** (Spec-u-la-tion).
  - *Revenue* → **3 syllables** (Rev-en-ue).
  - *Erode* → **2 syllables** (E-rode).
- **Stress Patterns**:
  - *"PROject"* (noun) vs. *"proJECT"* (verb).
- **Phonetic Sounds**:
  - Aspirated /p/ (e.g., *"people"* → **/p/** in "peo" is aspirated; "ple" is not).
  - Plural markers:
    - /s/ → After voiceless consonants (e.g., *"institutes"*).
    - /z/ → After voiced consonants/vowels (e.g., *"dogs"*).
    - /iz/ → After sibilants (e.g., *"boxes"*).
- **Semi-Vowels**:
  - /w/ → Transition between *"no"* and *"other"* (e.g., *"no other"* → /nəʊwʌðər/).

---

### **Mermaid Knowledge Graphs**
#### **1. Reading Comprehension (OpenAI Passage)**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[OpenAI Passage] --> B[Q* Model]
    A --> C[Sam Altman]
    A --> D[AGI Concerns]
    B --> B1[Solves unseen math]
    B --> B2[Staff warnings]
    C --> C1[Sacked]
    C --> C2[Reinstated]
    C --> C3[Microsoft support]
    D --> D1[Human control risks]
    D --> D2[Ethical AI]
```

#### **2. Grammar & Syntax**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Grammar] --> B[Punctuation]
    A --> C[Sentence Structure]
    A --> D[Tenses]
    B --> B1[Commas]
    B --> B2[Semicolons]
    C --> C1[Subject-Verb Agreement]
    C --> C2[Parallelism]
    D --> D1[Present Simple]
    D --> D2[Past Perfect]
```

#### **3. Vocabulary & Modal Verbs**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Vocabulary] --> B[Synonyms/Antonyms]
    A --> C[Idioms]
    A --> D[Modal Verbs]
    B --> B1[Trigger-Produce]
    B --> B2[Turmoil-Calm]
    C --> C1[Two peas in a pod]
    C --> C2[Sit on the fence]
    D --> D1[Could: Past ability]
    D --> D2[Should: Suggestion]
```

#### **4. Phonetics**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Phonetics] --> B[Syllables]
    A --> C[Stress]
    A --> D[Plural Markers]
    B --> B1[Speculation: 4]
    B --> B2[Revenue: 3]
    C --> C1[PROject vs. proJECT]
    D --> D1[/s/ in 'institutes']
    D --> D2[/z/ in 'dogs']
```

---

### **Exam Tips**
1. **Reading Comprehension**:
   - Skim for **main ideas** first, then read questions carefully.
   - Look for **signal words** (e.g., *"however," "therefore"*) to infer tone/purpose.
2. **Grammar**:
   - For sentence correction, **eliminate options** with clear errors (e.g., subject-verb mismatch).
   - Check for **parallel structure** in lists (e.g., *"restoring, installing, improving"*).
3. **Vocabulary**:
   - Use **context clues** for synonyms/antonyms.
   - For idioms, think of **literal vs. figurative** meanings.
4. **Phonetics**:
   - **Count syllables** by clapping or chin drops.
   - **Stress patterns**: Nouns often stress the **first syllable**; verbs stress the **second**.
